page.title: 18The Eagre
page.content: The River Trent is renowned for the Eagre or tidal bore,named after the chief of the norse sea-giants.It is very unpredictable and in some conditions the tide merely changes the flow of the river.At other times a wall of water four or five feet high rushes up the river at a speed of approximately twelve miles per hour,with sufficient power to upturn a barge.The tide flows for three hours and ebbs for nine hours.In the days of small craft it was the custom to shout "'Ware Eagre" to warn fellow boatmen of its approach.From low to high water the river may rise up to twelve feet.A second disturbance of water known as the "Whelps" follows the Eagre.This is caused by the division of the incoming tide at Reeds Island in the River Humber.
